Special thanks to @adutra and @olim7t who helped with translation things on the https://groups.google.com/a/lists.datastax.com/g/java-driver-user list

Closing mostly because
- number of spans is rarely a metric for observability, in this case indeed it seems to have been needed to troubleshoot buggy instrumentation
- this has not been requested by anyone else in the last four years

Also this: 

> We have cases where children are missing, think they may be our fault though. Also get odd cases where the UI displays the spans all as the lightest blue color rather than progressively darker colors as we nest into spans. Do you know the case that causes this UI behavior since the structure still appears, all be it a few spans are missing but the coloring is odd.

This should be checked against Lens, our new UI. I have a feeling that most of these issues were due to faulty instrumentation though. Something like https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/issues/1484 where we would be able to highlight in the UI common problems with span data would have probably helped here.

NOTE: biggest thing here is that `CASSANDRA_LOCAL_DC` env must be set to a valid value as the driver now requires it. We fall back to Cassandra's default of "datacenter1" when unset.

> I'm surprised you're still keeping the old cassandra storage.

@michaelsembwever This is mainly because cassandra3 relies on SASI which is still marked experimental. We can decide to unhook from that I suppose, and just implement the same indexing style we used before (except more efficient as in v2 model now)...
"cassandra3" looks working so far. kinks in "cassandra" not many. we are sorely missing docker tests :P will get to that in a week across the board.

Unintuitively, even after trimming jars, this results in a larger server binary than when we didn't share netty. The reason is querybuilder includes a massive dep on shaded guava (2.8m). I will remove that in a later PR.
schema takes about 10s to do now (currently happens per test).. which is intensely slowing tests probably beyond what travis will allow.

@odidev any progress your investigation ? Cassandra does have ARM64 docker images available.

@jorgheymans 
Yes, Cassandra does contain ARM64 support from version 3.11.0 and above. But Zipkin is using a zipkin-cassandra docker image, which is not available for ARM64. To build that docker image for ARM64, we would require Cassandra version 3.11.3 or above (Zipkin has a minimum cassandra version requirement of 3.11.3). However, I am able to successfully build a zipkin-cassandra docker image for ARM64 only with cassandra version 3.11.0. Higher versions of cassandra are showing below error:
~~~
ERROR [main] 2020-08-11 08:38:45,512 NativeLibraryLinux.java:64 - Failed to link the C library against JNA. Native methods will be unavailable.
java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError: /tmp/jna-3506402/jna6661864102162995724.tmp: Error loading shared library ld-linux-aarch64.so.1: No such file or directory (needed by /tmp/jna-3506402/jna6661864102162995724.tmp)
~~~
I have raised a JIRA in Cassandra for the ARM64 support in higher versions. Please find it here <https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CASSANDRA-16212#>
@jeqo I noticed we use run-kafka-class in the zipkin-storage-kafka image to create topics, hence I added it here

For the curious, JMX has been disabled on our main server for a very long time. We use Prometheus for metrics export.

Spring activator endpoints are the unofficial way to change log categories at runtime (not JMX).

Anyway, folks who really want JMX can make own image or complain.

Comparing latest 2.19.1 (left) with 2.22 (right):

Not collapsed:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/193792/97023744-3c6bca80-1556-11eb-9860-abc5a812aa25.png)

Collapsed:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/193792/97023826-5ad1c600-1556-11eb-8aa8-d34c0df05bd4.png)

@lambcode are you ok with this ? It's not what you asked for, but I guess not many people will know they're dealing with an orphaned span when it would not collapse along with the root, or what it evens means to have an orphaned span or what is causing it (instrumentation bug?).

My feeling is that from the UI side it should collapse with the root span since we're showing it as part of said root span anyway and it is connected to it. Anything else would be surprising to the user. Maybe a visual indication that the span is orphaned, but if we do so then we need to explain what it means. But i'm afraid we'ld be confusing people ? 

There is a more general issue on detecting common data issues that maybe this could be part of: https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/issues/1484 ? WDYT ?

The behavior shown does seem better than it was previously (no longer looks like a UI bug). I do wonder how orphaned spans would show if the root span is missing from the trace.

Long term, it would be nice if there was an indication that the trace contains orphaned spans and what those spans are. Without an indication it is easy to be unaware of instrumentation issues that cause them. If doing so is rolled up into #1484, that seems reasonable.

Thanks for the quick feedback @lambcode , going to close this issue then. There's a link to the common UI issues so we can backtrack here once it gets implemented.

This has actually been implemented at some point, here is a list of traces in Lens:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/193792/97087877-8e335400-162d-11eb-8ff7-134504043c10.png)

So when we then set minDuration to 20ms and maxDuration to 30ms, the only trace returned is 26.914ms which is correct.


![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/193792/97087916-bf138900-162d-11eb-91a0-4b3211a81445.png)

I have decided to close this issue, here's why
- MySQL is now considered a legacy storage option: `... no longer encouraged, but exist to help aid transition to supported ones. These are indicated as "v1" as they use data layouts based on Zipkin's V1 Thrift model, as opposed to the simpler v2 data model currently used.`
- The other comments about accepting unbounded POST requests and doing most of the request processing on the calling thread are no longer relevant since the switch to Armeria and most things are now being done asynchronous and reactive. For reference here is the current implementation of the collector doing the work: https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/5a8b26c476bfe710410f1ddfc38105355f1a7560/zipkin-server/src/main/java/zipkin2/server/internal/ZipkinHttpCollector.java#L105

Anyone feeling the need to revamp the MySQL storage option and bring it in line with the ElasticSearch and Cassandra v2 data model features is more than welcome to do so. Please ping our gitter channel before embarking on this effort !

Limiting in-flight requests has been a feature for a while of more recent Cassandra drivers. The original issue refers to issues during CI and these in particular seem to have been long solved. Cheers !

> The reason I'm asking is that I'm told if we internally use `EurekaUpdatingListenerBuilder`, we can register on startup, even in zipkin-slim, with no dependencies at all.


Note that the no-dependencies scenario no longer applies, see https://armeria.dev/docs/server-service-registration. Wondering if this could go in the fat-exec jar ?

maybe depends on how big it is and if we want to keep supporting it in the rare but possible case that armeria removes support for it. Another way is to package in contrib something like this that can be added to the server using the MODULE_OPTS we use for things like zipkin-aws? https://github.com/adriancole/zipkin-security

We still do not need extra dependencies.
https://github.com/line/armeria/blob/master/eureka/build.gradle
You can see that there's no dependencies needed.

Ah, we made the separate module for eureka which just uses the dependencies that Armeria uses.

The jar looks like it is only 54k so no biggie. Now we are down to configuration (and relevance)

While URL and instance ID are minimal, there are other properties
```
        EurekaUpdatingListener.builder("https://eureka.com:8001/eureka/v2");
                              .instanceId("i-00000000")
                              .setHostname("armeria.service.1")
                              // If ipAddr is not specified, it's automatically filled
                              // using SystemInfo.defaultNonLoopbackIpV4Address().
                              .ipAddr("192.168.10.10")
                              .vipAddress("armeria.service.com:8080");
```

For example, we had a lot of requests for eureka and some for [nacos](https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/issues/2540). Not sure how popular eureka is still. If it is, we can consider designing an integration either bundled or opt-in.

copying @XuefengChen @george24601 @chuguoren @charims @zoidbergwill @ezraroi @thekalinga @zerocode @lumiseven who 👍 this and @MaciejGawel @Jungle666 who mentioned this in other issues.

If you want eureka, please thumbs up this comment if you want this in the default server. If you don't reply back otherwise, the config will be limited to hard-coding the instanceId to "zipkin-server" and activated by a variable like EUREKA_URL

Note that if eureka itself becomes a canceled technology, or armeria stops supporting it, so would we.

Is RocketMQ and PostgresQL supported?

FYI: due to the impending docker hub rate limit crisis, we've recently redone our docker image structure, and also push to ghcr.io

It seems we've met rule of three on this one.

It is good if folks could actively reply back with exactly which arch they need as it is helpful when considering effort. For example, I think internally we might be interested in arm64 if that has anything to do with docker not booting in Travis' LXD envs..

@dmfrey @msfussell @yaron2 @artursouza can you comment back on what you need precisely?

also, unless someone mentions otherwise, I'm assuming we are talking about these two images:

openzipkin/zipkin (full featured with kafka etc)
openzipkin/zipkin-slim (smaller images with only in-mem and Elasticsearch support)

When commenting back, please mention which images you use, especially if it isn't the ones I said.

I don't think folks will become disinterested over this, but bear in mind if we switch to multi-arch, we use double the Docker Hub pull quota from Nov 1 forward. For example, authenticated accounts get 200 normal pulls/6hrs or 100 multi-arch ones. In other words only folks using ghcr.io or a paid docker hub account would be completely unaffected. Folks who don't care about this, if I understand correctly, will use more of their quota without obvious benefit to them. Not suggesting we wouldn't proceed anyway, just putting it out there. cc @openzipkin/core

please use https://gitter.im/openzipkin/zipkin to chat, but don't duplicate issues.

#2620 is for rocketmq
#1232 is for PostgresQL

You can add your interest on these issues.

both would need someone to help create and maintain the support. PostgresQL would be much more work because storage is more difficult. Please reply on https://gitter.im/openzipkin/zipkin if you want to chat more.
merging on winky build as this branch doesn't apply unless on master anyway. thanks for the look @anuraaga!

Hi,

I have the same issue. My zipkin version is 2.21.7.

Let me explain it with this simple trace. This is a clean trace without any problems, like we want to have it. 
![trace_full](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5988272/97496941-053c5580-196a-11eb-80a0-f83001881871.png)
Download: https://gist.github.com/stuckyhm/ecf9b66ef8a0f6b3b441b1dacb94eb1f#file-trace_full-json

But sometimes it isn't so easy and spans are going lost. There are saveral reasons for this, which zipkin is basically not responsible for.
- There may be a network outage, especially if you are using UDP for transport.
- There may be an missconfiguration in an service (e.g. wrong zipkin api url).
- There may be an bug in the instrumentation.
- There may be an incorrect integration of the instrumentation.

All this and some more could be a reason for lossing spans. Let us asume the spans 1 and 2 are missing. Zipkin will render the trace like this:
![trace_missing_spans](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5988272/97496971-12594480-196a-11eb-8a58-e37b97307735.png)
Download: https://gist.github.com/stuckyhm/e06bfddaf265e5a9546ca42b777c6cdd#file-trace_missing_spans-json

It isn't usefull anymore. You can say: Fix that instrumentation and try it again. 

This is good advice and needs to be done, but it does not help us with our current problem that we are trying to analyze. It needs time to fix the instrumentation and possibly redeploy of one or more services. Time we in this moment not have. Monitoring and tracing has often not the highest priority. Or worse, it's a third-party module that we can't fix and we have to wait for the vendor.

Our job is to deal with errors and bugs. So zipkin should be more tolerant of faulty traces.

My idea is to add dynamically an dummy span that collects this multi maybe root spans. It could look like this:
![trace_missing_spans_patch](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5988272/97497007-20a76080-196a-11eb-9ba4-2532bad1e220.png)

I created a simple patch for the file _src/zipkin/span-node.js_ that can do this. Please take look if this is a way we can go. 
https://gist.github.com/stuckyhm/dc8c696b0d0addbb64d08b1cd8fbc5e9#file-span-node-js-patch

If you agree with me I can create a pull request. I will then try to create the tests for it. And I'm not sure if this is the right position for this fix.

I am happy to hear from you.
I was wrong.. multi-arch is 2 manifests, but they count as a single pull request https://docs.docker.com/docker-hub/download-rate-limit/

The current requests for multi-arch boil down to rpi k8s cluster and the https://dapr.io/ project. In both of these cases, it is about arm64, the latter seemingly supporting arm (not 64)

```
ifeq ($(TARGET_ARCH),arm)
  DOCKER_IMAGE_PLATFORM:=$(TARGET_OS)/arm/v7
else ifeq ($(TARGET_ARCH),arm64)
  DOCKER_IMAGE_PLATFORM:=$(TARGET_OS)/arm64/v8
else
  DOCKER_IMAGE_PLATFORM:=$(TARGET_OS)/amd64
endif

# Supported docker image architecture
DOCKERMUTI_ARCH=linux-amd64 linux-arm linux-arm64 windows-amd64
```

I think this boils down to *amd64 arm and arm64* and to do this we have to check zulu (JRE) + alpine, possibly refactor our base image.

Hi, Dapr maintainer here.

Dapr installs a bunch of supporting containers, among them is Zipkin for tracing. Some of our users are trying to install this on RPI cluster or ARM VMs and running into an issue with Zipkin.

Our alternative at this point is to bundle Dapr with a different tracing backend that supports the ARM arch.
@yaron2 can you confirm if you need arm 32bit or not?

Incidentally, I'm not sure if actually our server will operate well in 32bit arch.. @trustin @anuraaga @minwoox is there anything armeria or netty related that assumes 64bit (native side)? It might be best for us to start with 64bit arm and only upon demand do 32..

> @yaron2 can you confirm if you need arm 32bit or not?

arm64 will be fine to start with.

@stuckyhm Thank you for offing to help. We have a "synthetic root node" heuristic check. The root of the tree is synthetic when node.span is undefined. https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/master/zipkin-lens/src/zipkin/span-node.js#L25

I think what needs to happen is when we find multiple roots is to demote the former to a child of a synthetic root. EG move the prior to a child of a new root node, and perhaps set a boolean "multipleRoots" to prevent later duplicate roots from asserting themselves.

In other words, we want to retain the behavior of synthetic root when there is no root (existing tests pass)
we add a behaviour of multiple roots are under a synthetic root (new tests I guess)
then finally a visualization for either of the above cases, but more importantly when there are multiple roots.

I don't know if UX wise a fake root span is better or a different rendering, but a fake root span like you are showing here is probably fine.

Hope these notes lead in the right way and are relevant. We will be doing a release in the next day or two for the Docker Hub rate limit problem, but we can also release this later if doesn't land in time.

So the base java image we are using is alpine+zulu. It isn't multi-arch, but there's a good chance that can be made so. Will test and if it works, this should be able to go in shortly. Either way, will report back.

@driesdeproost are you in a position to test this again ? Many improvements have been made on the list view since then. I have tested it for my site and had several hundreds of traces in the overview of which many had several thousands of spans.

In current Lens, the span detail view has moved out from being a dropdown to a permanent panel on the right. The service and span name are prominently visible, and being no longer close to the actual span location in the trace tree that's actually a good thing.  

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/193792/97629790-e227a980-1a2e-11eb-8167-9c0a8eafb6eb.png)

Closing this as no longer relevant, if you have other suggestion how to improve the trace detail view feel free to open a new ticket.

I think Lens should excel in 2 parts: 1) finding a trace, and 2) making sense of said trace. Lets focus on this and make these bits really great. 

A graphical representation of a collection of traces could be useful but is hard to get right and does not always lead to finding a trace quicker. Also it gives the false impression (to me at least) we're venturing into metrics land.

@houseyoung would you mind testing those huge traces against the latest version of Zipkin ? The new UI has seen many performance improvements and i doubt that it would take 40s to render a huge trace. Also if you're in a position to anonymize the trace and upload it into a gist that would be great, so we can use it as a test case.
https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/3270 should do it

@anuraaga I wanted to run this by you before proceeding
@odidev I think this actually will simplify arm builds on travis and otherwise

a hint on this, when running tests, testcontainers runs docker for our storage tests (ex ITCassandraStorage). right now, the images are pointed to the last release which not multi-arch. after a successful green build on travis, you can swap these for :master tag. ex "openzipkin/zipkin-cassandra:2.21.7" -> "openzipkin/zipkin-cassandra:master"

if the arch doesn't have a working docker, tests might pass too quickly because it is ignoring the docker tests

zipkin and zipkin-slim are dual arch now, both on docker hub and github container registry

Running via Docker:
```bash
# Note: this is mirrored as ghcr.io/openzipkin/zipkin-slim
docker run -d -p 9411:9411 openzipkin/zipkin-slim
```

![Screen Shot 2020-10-31 at 11 00 57 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64215/97782531-f86b6c00-1bcc-11eb-9c80-b16659343f17.png)

https://github.com/orgs/openzipkin/packages/container/package/zipkin

Thanks for the suggestion, I do agree that it does sound useful - to some extent. But the fact that this has not sparked any discussion or reaction after almost four years indicates that most users are probably ok with not having this feature. In any case, implementing this would not be a small feat as @sambishop hints, as the required modifications to the search syntax need to be supported and implemented for all our storage backends. Since we're a small team, we don't implement new storage features lightly unless there's very high and obvious demand for it. 

Closing, feel free to reopen if you still feel strongly about this, or consider raising a PR to get things going.

Closing, as the linked issue #1492 contains the useful discussion. It would have been helpful to include an anonymized version of the trace so that it's very easy to check if your case has been corrected since then.

Not sure if the view that span collection is the most performance critical still applies. A laggy and slow UI makes users turn away from zipkin and not want to use it ...

The idea was insightful at the time though, observability was novel territory back then. I doubt though that we can easily provide something that will work for all sites. Most low traffic sites won't need this, and the high traffic sites are most likely well enough staffed that they can take care of this themselves. We would just end up in a whole range of support issues we don't want to get involved with. 

 Closing this one, if you still feel there's merit pursuing this feel free to reopen.

3.5 years later, and nobody stepped up to carry the idea forward or voice interest in it. I'm going to close this, feel free to reopen if you think there is still some merit in the idea or it's worth reviving it for some reason.

It's nearing on 5 years since this idea was floated. Apart from that, the idea of using the dependency diagram to track adoption stats has never really caught on.

Other than that, this issue is notable as we see @michaelsembwever [foretell](https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/issues/914#issuecomment-177108525) the Forking of Zipkin.
The question was answered, has not received any further comments in a while so closing.

This issue relates to the classic Zipkin UI. Lens has seen many performance improvements since then. Having testing with 10k span traces myself, i see these loading in just in 7-8 seconds on my laptop. UX wise this can still be improved sure, but it's definitely a major improvement over classic UI.

If you're considering posting similar issues against Lens, please provide us with an anonymized version of your slow loading trace so we can benchmark and profile it.

I agree with @eirslett that sites using the trace data to manage their architecture dependencies should build such capability themselves outside of Zipkin. 

@fedj are you ok with closing this ?

@anuraaga did the bulk of this with testcontainers. I think the general process could be lifted by another into multi-node somehow https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/master/benchmarks/src/test/java/zipkin2/server/ServerIntegratedBenchmark.java

I've temporarily pushed a mirror to our github registry

```Dockerfile
ARG version=3.8.9
ARG image=rabbitmq:$version-management-alpine
FROM $image
LABEL org.opencontainers.image.description="Internal to Zipkin. Do not use in production. Mirror of $image as no alternate registry to docker.io is known, yet. See #3279"
LABEL org.opencontainers.image.source=https://github.com/docker-library/rabbitmq
LABEL org.opencontainers.image.version=$version
```

```bash
$ docker buildx build --platform linux/amd64,linux/arm64 -t ghcr.io/openzipkin/rabbitmq-management-alpine:latest --push .
```
